title: Pyne shows EY delegation around naval conference
text:
Christopher Pyne already has a lot on his plate. Alex Ellinghausen

Under fire for hiring Christopher Pyne within weeks of his leaving office, EY insisted he'd barely be doing anything at all.

He'd simply provide "occasional high-level strategic advice", an EY spokeswoman said. Defence industry leader Mark Stewart later told parliament this would involve the former defence minister working for EY "two days a month". Which hardly sounds like anything worth getting upset about.

Attendees at the Pacific International Maritime Exposition got a first-hand glance at what exactly such minimal work entails. Pyne was there, with an EY delegation that included Stewart, getting plenty of face time with the decision-makers of Australia's defence procurement industry. Which, for EY, must have been handy.

And it gave attendees a chance to catch up with all things Pyne, who five months after leaving parliament seems to have a lot on his plate. Between his lobbying and his new podcast (the first episode drops on Monday), we hear he has a book to write for publishing doyen Louise Adler, formerly of Melbourne University Press. Seems she's still giving politicians all the rope they need at her new employer Hachette.
description: Under fire for hiring Christopher Pyne within weeks of his leaving office, EY insisted he'd barely be doing anything at all.
